loading="lazy"></picture></a></div><div class="Card_wrapper-text__U6Y3k"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c Card_content-block__pF6Z1"><span>Executive Briefing - <i>McKinsey Quarterly</i></span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-ceo-guide-to-customer-experience" class="mdc-c-link-heading___Zggl8_990311c mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c"><div>The CEO guide to customer experience</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"The ongoing trouble with travel distribution Customer experience","displayName":"The ongoing trouble with travel distribution Customer experience","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"9b156868-de20-47a9-922d-762daae3fedd","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The (ongoing) trouble with travel distribution: Customer experience"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The industry’s rapid evolution continues unabated. To profit through this turbulence, leaders must focus on what really matters—the customer."}},"sEODescription":{"value":""},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2017-02-27T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]] [[DisruptorSignUp left]]\n\u003cp\u003e\n\u003cstrong\u003eThe landscape of travel distribution\u003c/strong\u003e has been shifting. Until the mid-1990s, distribution was a straightforward mix of brand call centers, travel agencies, and in-person bookings at the hotel front desk, airline ticket counter, or car-rental outpost.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote1\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e1\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote1\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e1.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nIn hotels, for example, the launch of the Holiday Inn booking website in June 1995 marked the beginning of a turbulent assault on owner profit margins, brand value proposition, and the viability of independence.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The launch of online booking gave companies a new way to engage with customers and also opened the door to new business models such as online travel agencies (OTAs). However, in the 2000s, most travel suppliers, aggregators, and service providers focused on managing transaction costs rather than improving the customer experience, with serious implications. In 2012, we wrote about the \u0026ldquo;trouble\u0026rdquo; with travel distribution, noting, \u0026ldquo;The game is now about delivering a superior customer experience.\u0026rdquo;\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote2\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e2\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote2\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e2.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nRobert Carey, David Kang, and Michael Zea, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-transport-and-logistics/our-insights/the-trouble-with-travel-distribution\"\u003eThe trouble with travel distribution\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; February 2012.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nSince then, the pace of change has accelerated due to three factors. First, the competitive bar continues to rise. Among OTAs, three leading players\u0026mdash;Ctrip, Expedia, and Priceline\u0026mdash;have achieved global scale and relevance. And suppliers are seeking a competitive edge through several levers, including loyalty partnerships; building on the foundation set by Delta and Starwood, today\u0026rsquo;s major travel partnerships include those between Starwood and Uber, United and Marriott, and Qantas and Airbnb, among others. Second, travel technologies\u0026mdash;especially mobile platforms\u0026mdash;have continued to evolve as customers alter how they browse for and purchase travel. Expedia reports that 40 to 60 percent of its leisure-travel-brand traffic is through mobile devices, and about half of bookings on some brands comes from mobile.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote3\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e3\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote3\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e3.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n\u0026ldquo;Edited transcript: EXPE\u0026mdash;Q3 2016 Expedia Inc earnings call,\u0026rdquo; Thomson Reuters Streetevents, October 27, 2016, files.shareholder.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Third, potential sources of disruption are on the horizon. For example, business travel currently accounts for 10 percent of Airbnb bookings\u0026mdash;but that number is growing, thanks to the company\u0026rsquo;s integration into the platforms of several leading travel-management companies.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote4\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e4\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote4\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e4.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nDan Peltier, \u0026ldquo;Airbnb scores another win with corporate travel management integration,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, July 12, 2016, skift.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe shifting conditions make it more important than ever to put the customer at the center. But despite some examples of progress, we continue to see companies solve for business requirements over customer needs. Many suppliers are falling short of their potential because they focus on transaction costs instead of lifetime value. And for many intermediaries, earnings expectations, contentious supplier relationships, and an onslaught of digital newcomers have eroded the ability to test, learn, and \u0026ldquo;fail fast\u0026rdquo; that helped them identify and solve unmet needs in the first place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe good news? The path to success is likely more straightforward than it seems. In fact, we see examples of companies implementing some or all of the strategies we will discuss:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n1. Harness advanced analytics to understand the customer better.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n2. Adjust mobile offerings to capture, secure, and serve the customer.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\n3. Safeguard against future disruption.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nWhat\u0026rsquo;s the catch? Unless executives focus relentlessly on solving for customer needs, we will continue to see ineffective promotions, lackluster apps, and uninspired pivots and product launches. Companies that can solve real customer needs, including through partnerships with other members of the travel ecosystem, will position themselves at the vanguard of travel distribution.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e\nTrends in the shifting distribution landscape\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nFrom travelers to technology, several significant trends are influencing how companies engage with customers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\nSuppliers are emboldened to innovate product development, marketing, and distribution\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIntermediaries connect suppliers with consumers, but such bookings come at a cost. Thus, suppliers are pursuing strategies to drive more direct bookings:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eLaunching large-scale marketing campaigns.\u003c/em\u003e For example, Hilton\u0026rsquo;s \u0026ldquo;Stop Clicking Around\u0026rdquo; campaign, along with other initiatives, contributed to a 60 percent increase in HHonors enrollments and a shift toward direct channels in the third quarter of 2016.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote5\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e5\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote5\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e5.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u0026ldquo;Hilton Worldwide Holdings, Inc.: Q3 2016 earning call,\u0026rdquo; Hilton, October 26, 2016, ir.hiltonworldwide.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eEnhancing direct-channel offerings.\u003c/em\u003e AccorHotels has begun distributing independent hotels through AccorHotels.com at up to 14 percent commission and plans to reach more than 8,000 properties over time.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote6\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e6\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote6\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e6.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Terence Baker, \u0026ldquo;Accor\u0026rsquo;s distribution gamble takes shape,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eHotel News Now\u003c/em\u003e, September 23, 2015, hotelnewsnow.com; Deanna Ting, \u0026ldquo;AccorHotels CEO to the hotels industry: \u0026lsquo;You have an obligation to be bold,\u0026rsquo;\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, August 5, 2016, skift.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eProviding disincentives for indirect bookings.\u003c/em\u003e In September 2015, Lufthansa implemented a \u0026euro;16 fee for bookings made through global distribution systems (GDSs). While Lufthansa and third parties differ in their assessment of the fee\u0026rsquo;s impact, the move helps enable a longer-term shift to more dynamic pricing.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote7\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e7\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote7\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e7.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Martin Cowen, \u0026ldquo;Lufthansa flatbats DCC questions,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eTnooz\u003c/em\u003e, November 16, 2016, tnooz.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eConsolidating to achieve scale.\u003c/em\u003e Among US airlines, mergers over the past ten years have led to four clear leaders with combined 80 percent domestic market share (and Alaska Air recently became the fifth-leading carrier, with 6 percent share, after the acquisition of Virgin America).\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote8\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e8\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote8\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e8.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Susan Carey and Brent Kendall, \u0026ldquo;Alaska Air-Virgin America merger gets US approval,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eWall Street Journal\u003c/em\u003e, December 6, 2016, wsj.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003e\nWhile the specific strategy varies by supplier, the trend is clear: suppliers throughout the travel industry are willing to go further than ever to convince customers to book directly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\nIntermediaries are consolidating and expanding their footprint\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThree leading OTAs\u0026mdash;Expedia, Priceline, and Ctrip\u0026mdash;also own (at least for now) the world\u0026rsquo;s leading metasearch players.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote9\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e9\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote9\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e9.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n\u0026ldquo;Metasearch\u0026rdquo; refers to companies such as Kayak and Trivago that aggregate search results from several travel websites.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Each continues to assume, in its own way, an expanded role in the customer journey:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Expedia (which recorded $61 billion in 2015 gross bookings) acquired Orbitz and Travelocity in 2015. It is the clear leader in the United States, with approximately two-thirds OTA market share. It is present in many travel verticals, including metasearch (Trivago), vacation rentals (HomeAway), and corporate travel (Egencia).\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote10\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e10\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote10\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e10.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Angelo Rossini, \u0026ldquo;State of online travel agencies: Ctrip joins Priceline and Expedia as global giant,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, July 7, 2016, skift.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Priceline ($56 billion in 2015 gross bookings) is the largest player by revenue and market value, given strength in hotels through Booking.com. The clear leader in Europe, it is also present in many travel verticals, including metasearch (Kayak.com), vacation rentals (Booking.com), and restaurant bookings (OpenTable). It owns a 9 percent stake in Ctrip.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote11\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e11\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote11\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e11.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Rossini, \u0026ldquo;State of online travel agencies\u0026rdquo;; Gerrit De Vynck, \u0026ldquo;Priceline takes $941 million charge; earnings beat estimates,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eBloomberg\u003c/em\u003e, November 7, 2016, bloomberg.com; Dennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;Exclusive: Ctrip CEO on global ambitions, Skyscanner buy and the Priceline relationship,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, November 28, 2016, skift.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Ctrip ($27 billion in 2015 gross bookings) is the fastest-growing global OTA, with a growth rate of 58 percent in 2015 alone. It is the clear leader in Chinese domestic and outbound travel and is a mobile leader, with an estimated 70 percent of bookings via app. It is consolidating its position in Asia through stakes in Qunar, eLong, and MakeMyTrip. It also has an expanding presence in many travel verticals, including metasearch (Skyscanner) and tour operators.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote12\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e12\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote12\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e12.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Rossini, \u0026ldquo;State of online travel agencies\u0026rdquo;; Dennis Schall, \u0026ldquo;Exclusive: Ctrip CEO on how it moves in to buy Skyscanner,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, November 25, 2016, skift.com; Dennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;China\u0026rsquo;s Ctrip makes strategic investments in 3 U.S. tour operators,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, October 25, 2016, skift.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThese giants, along with Google and TripAdvisor, will continue to play a major role in shaping the future of distribution.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote13\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e13\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote13\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e13.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nFor a summary of recent moves, including Book on Google and Trips, see Dennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;Google\u0026rsquo;s travel business is already twice the size of Expedia\u0026rsquo;s,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, November 1, 2016, skift.com. To hear directly from Google, see Dennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;Video: Google\u0026rsquo;s travel leader on paid links and being a booking player,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, October 27, 2016, skift.com. For details on TripAdvisor\u0026rsquo;s Instant Booking, see Dennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;Video: TripAdvisor CEO is committed to instant booking and long-term growth,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, October 31, 2016, skift.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e In many cases, the relationship between these intermediaries, and between intermediaries and suppliers, is multifaceted. As recently as 2014, analysts estimated that Expedia and Priceline accounted for up to 5 percent of Google\u0026rsquo;s total ad revenue.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote14\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e14\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote14\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e14.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nRolfe Winkler and Craig Karmin, \u0026ldquo;Google checks in to the hotel business,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eWall Street Journal\u003c/em\u003e, April 8, 2014, wsj.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Marriott partners with Expedia to sell dynamic travel packages through Vacations by Marriott.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote15\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e15\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote15\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e15.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nKevin May, \u0026ldquo;OTAs aren\u0026rsquo;t so bad after all\u0026mdash;Expedia to power Marriott packages channel,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eTnooz\u003c/em\u003e, September 6, 2016, tnooz.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e And Southwest Airlines\u0026rsquo; hotel offerings are provided by Priceline\u0026rsquo;s Booking.com.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote16\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e16\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote16\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e16.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nDennis Schaal, \u0026ldquo;Booking.com powers hotels for Southwest, its first U.S. airline,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, November 2, 2016, skift.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e The continued evolution of intermediary business models will be critical to watch.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\nCustomer behavior is maturing and shifting to mobile\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nMobile is increasingly the customer\u0026rsquo;s channel of choice: by 2019, nearly 80 percent of US travelers who book online will do so via mobile, up from 36 percent in 2014.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote17\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e17\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote17\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e17.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n\u0026ldquo;By 2016, most digital travel bookers will use mobile devices,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eeMarketer\u003c/em\u003e, November 19, 2015, emarketer.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u0026ldquo;Mobile first\u0026rdquo; has become a favorite catchphrase, but given the massive shift in behavior, travel companies must develop a deep understanding of why and how customers are using mobile. Consider, for example, the following trends:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Mobile search is on the rise. In 2015, mobile flight and hotel searches on Google increased 33 and 49 percent year over year, respectively.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote18\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e18\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote18\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e18.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u0026ldquo;Travel Dashboard\u0026mdash;a look back at recent trends,\u0026rdquo; Google, thinkwithgoogle.com, accessed\n    November 29, 2016.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Mobile plays a critical role after arrival. For instance, 85 percent of leisure travelers choose activities after their arrival, and half of international travelers use their mobile devices to search for such activities after their arrival.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote19\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e19\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote19\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e19.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u0026ldquo;Travel trends 2016: Data reveals hot spots and new consumer insights,\u0026rdquo; Google, September 2016, thinkwithgoogle.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Not all mobile experiences are created equal. The average rating of OTA/metasearch apps is 19 percent higher than the average of hotel brand apps.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote20\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e20\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote20\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e20.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    McKinsey analysis of Apple App Store data, August 2015.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe industry has seen some recent mobile-focused innovations. These include day-of-travel features such as keyless or app-enabled hotel room entry, in-app passport scanning at check-in, and real-time luggage tracking. Other developments involve context-based design; for example, 24 hours before a scheduled flight, Virgin America\u0026rsquo;s app shifts from emphasizing booking to focusing on check-in.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote21\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e21\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote21\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e21.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nDiana Budds, \u0026ldquo;Virgin America\u0026rsquo;s new app puts a travel agent in your pocket,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eFast Company\u003c/em\u003e, July 28, 2016, fastcodesign.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Finally, a growing list of brands across the value chain\u0026mdash;including Booking.com, Cheapflights, Expedia, Hyatt, Kayak, KLM, Lola, and Skyscanner\u0026mdash;have introduced messaging platforms and bots.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote22\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e22\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote22\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e22.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nDen Peltier, \u0026ldquo;Travel bots on messaging platforms are the trend now,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, June 14, 2016, skift.com; Marisa Garcia, \u0026ldquo;Icelandair and Travelaer build airline industry\u0026rsquo;s first Facebook Messenger booking bot,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eTnooz\u003c/em\u003e, August 3, 2016, tnooz.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nLooking forward, booking may be the function ripest for innovation, as relatively few players have created a compelling, mobile-friendly booking experience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\nProliferation of big data and advanced analytics\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nAs our colleagues recently wrote, \u0026ldquo;The data analytics revolution now under way has the potential to transform how companies organize, operate, manage talent, and create value. That\u0026rsquo;s starting to happen in a few companies\u0026mdash;typically ones that are reaping major rewards from their data\u0026mdash;but it\u0026rsquo;s far from the norm.\u0026rdquo;\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote23\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e23\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote23\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e23.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nHelen Mayhew, Tamim Saleh, and Simon Williams, \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/business-functions/digital-mckinsey/our-insights/making-data-analytics-work-for-you-instead-of-the-other-way-around\"\u003eMaking data analytics work for you\u0026mdash;instead of the other way around\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey Quarterly\u003c/em\u003e, October 2016.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e This truth certainly holds in travel, where a wide range of use cases is emerging:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eEnhancing commercial effectiveness.\u003c/em\u003e Red Roof Inn used analytics on publicly available weather and flight data to predict and target customers facing flight cancellations.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote24\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e24\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote24\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e24.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Sunil Gupta, \u0026ldquo;In mobile advertising, timing is everything,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eHarvard Business Review\u003c/em\u003e, November 4, 2015, hbr.org.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eRefining customer experience.\u003c/em\u003e British Airways\u0026rsquo; \u0026ldquo;Know Me\u0026rdquo; program, driven partially by Opera Solutions, mines customer data including loyalty information and buying habits to generate targeted offers and experiences.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote25\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e25\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote25\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e25.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u0026ldquo;Big data at British Airways,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eCIO2CIO Middle East\u003c/em\u003e, January 12, 2014, cio2cio.me.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eOptimizing network and portfolio.\u003c/em\u003e Aloft, for example, is piloting a digital hotel experience, with rooms equipped with Internet of Things\u0026ndash;enabled technologies such as intelligent climate control, and using the data generated to support product innovation.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote26\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e26\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote26\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e26.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Nancy Trejos, \u0026ldquo;Aloft Hotels debut voice-activated rooms,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eUSA Today\u003c/em\u003e, August 30, 2016, usatoday.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eDriving operational and administrative efficiency.\u003c/em\u003e Hotels are using platforms such as ALICE (which counts Expedia as an investor) to consolidate, track, and analyze guest requests and interactions to improve the quality and speed of operations.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote27\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e27\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote27\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e27.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Sean O\u0026rsquo;Neill, \u0026ldquo;ALICE thinks hotel operations could learn from innovation in other industries,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eTnooz\u003c/em\u003e, August 18, 2016, tnooz.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nBefore embarking on new big data or analytics ventures, it is critical to ensure adequate data security\u0026mdash;particularly given the numerous high-profile, highly damaging data breaches in other industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\n\u0026lsquo;New\u0026rsquo; and increasingly powerful business models emerging\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe sharing or on-demand economy, exemplified by companies such as Airbnb and Uber, is the most significant business model to emerge and scale over the past five years. The numbers themselves are notable\u0026mdash;including rapid growth (Piper Jaffray estimates a 10 percent compound annual growth rate for short-term and peer-to-peer accommodations from 2014 to 2025, versus 3 percent for traditional accommodations\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote28\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e28\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote28\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e28.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nMichael J. Olson and Samuel J. Kemp, \u003cem\u003eSharing economy: An in-depth look at its evolution and trajectory across industries\u003c/em\u003e, Piper Jaffray, March 2015, collaborativeeconomy.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e) and valuations (including Uber at $68 billion, Didi Chuxing at $33 billion, and Airbnb at $30 billion\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote29\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e29\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote29\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e29.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nScott Austin, Chris Canipe, and Sarah Slobin, \u0026ldquo;The billion dollar startup club,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eWall Street Journal\u003c/em\u003e, February 18, 2015, wsj.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e). But more interesting is the degree to which innovative current players continue to innovate:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Uber\u0026rsquo;s expansion continues not only into new cities but also into new modes of transportation. In a recently published white paper, the company laid out the potential for vertical take-off and landing (VTOL) aircraft for on-demand transportation, particularly in dense urban networks.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote30\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e30\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote30\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e30.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eFast-forwarding to a future of on-demand urban air transportation\u003c/em\u003e, Uber, October 27, 2016, uber.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Airbnb\u0026rsquo;s recently announced expansion into Trips (peer-to-peer tours and activities ranging from a few hours to a few days) and Places (including meet-ups with other users, destination guides, local recommendations, audio guides, and eventually, restaurant reservations) represents the latest step in a journey from air mattresses in spare rooms to a \u0026ldquo;super brand of travel.\u0026rdquo;\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote31\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e31\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote31\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e31.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Deanna Ting, \u0026ldquo;Airbnb launches Trips, its big tours and activities gamble,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eSkift.com\u003c/em\u003e, November 17, 2016, skift.com. We highly recommend listening to the story of Airbnb\u0026rsquo;s founding; see \u003cem\u003eHow I built this\u003c/em\u003e, \u0026ldquo;Airbnb: Joe Gebbia,\u0026rdquo; NPR podcast, October 17, 2016, npr.org. Some observers, particularly Airbnb\u0026rsquo;s newfound competitors in tours and activities, are not sold on the potential of Trips; see Tony Carne, \u0026ldquo;How to burst the bubble of Airbnb Trips in two phone calls,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eTnooz\u003c/em\u003e, November 21, 2016, tnooz.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nWhile hospitality and ground transportation have been most heavily disrupted, other modes such as air travel also continue to see innovation from models such as Rise, Surf Air, OneGo, and Set Jet. Beyond the sharing economy, specialized models continue to emerge  with a focus on capturing an outsize share of specific segments. For example, Priceline founder Jay Walker\u0026rsquo;s Upside rewards \u0026ldquo;free agent\u0026rdquo; business travelers for flexibility in flight and hotel bookings.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote32\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e32\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote32\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e32.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nKirsten Korosec, \u0026ldquo;Priceline founder launches new company aimed at business travelers,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e, June 21, 2016, fortune.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar sidebar1]]\n\u003ch2\u003e\nWhat really matters\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nExecutives should resist the temptation to be pulled in directions that distract from their top priorities: engaging with customers more effectively, enhancing attraction and retention, and capturing more value throughout the customer life cycle. To begin the process of thinking in terms of customer lifetime value instead of cost per booking, they must answer some fundamental questions:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eHow much is a customer worth?\u003c/em\u003e In banking and many other industries, analyzing and predicting a customer\u0026rsquo;s lifetime value at acquisition is standard operating procedure. In travel, we\u0026rsquo;ve encountered very few companies that conduct this analysis consistently or at scale, despite the available data on marketing, transactions, loyalty, satisfaction, and referrals.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eWhat can every employee do to secure the next purchase?\u003c/em\u003e Customer acquisition and retention can no longer be the purview of marketing and sales groups alone. Everything from back-office accounting to human resources to maintenance must be oriented toward enhancing the lifetime value of each customer.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eHow do customer needs and booking scenarios influence the choice of booking channel?\u003c/em\u003e Companies must identify and exploit the many \u0026ldquo;micro moments\u0026rdquo; in the customer journey. This journey should be mapped starting with the inspiration for the trip and combined with factors such as the customer\u0026rsquo;s location at point of purchase, the device used, historical preferences, and past experiences to deliver the right offer through the right channel at the right time.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n[[sidebar sidebar2]]\n\u003cp\u003e\nFocusing on these three strategies\u0026mdash;and executing each of them in a more customer-focused way\u0026mdash;will position companies for success amid the continued turbulence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\n1. Harness advanced analytics to understand the customer better\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe often hear travel companies talking about the advances they\u0026rsquo;ve made in creating \u0026ldquo;integrated data views,\u0026rdquo; but many cannot articulate positive, bottom-line impact. Compare that with these examples:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    OTAs are currently experimenting with facial-recognition software to personalize recommendations. In fact, they have been using similar methods to improve website conversion for years.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote33\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e33\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote33\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e33.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Drake Bennett, \u0026ldquo;Expedia thinks it can help you find the dream vacation you didn\u0026rsquo;t know you wanted,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eBloomberg Businessweek\u003c/em\u003e, February 25, 2016, bloomberg.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Providers that use analytics to help companies boost revenue and customer satisfaction, such as Optiontown, Plusgrade, and Boxever, are expanding quickly.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Airlines are now collecting customer information on board. For example, Delta uses a \u0026ldquo;guest service tool\u0026rdquo; to identify key information such as frequent-flier status and tight connection times.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote34\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e34\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote34\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e34.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Justin Bachman, \u0026ldquo;American ends in-flight gate announcements,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eLas Vegas Review-Journal\u003c/em\u003e, May 16, 2016, reviewjournal.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e On loyalty, airlines are moving beyond traditional award charts to dynamically linking redemption to value.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    Hotels are exploring ways to combine site-selection models with new sources of information, such as Airbnb data; apply machine learning to enhance forecasting models for yield and revenue management; and deliver personalized, real-time offers based on a guest\u0026rsquo;s past behavior, current location, and propensity to buy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe key difference? Starting with and focusing on the customer. While our research across industries suggests there are four key building blocks to ensure a successful analytics transformation, determining which customer needs can be solved with analytics must come before thinking about the data you have and need.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003estrategy:\u003c/em\u003e a detailed definition of the vision, a specific plan and milestones to be achieved, and the selection of the most effective use cases based on customer needs\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eorganization:\u003c/em\u003e a targeted governance model that includes data owners and committees, clear data-aggregation and integrity-management processes, and alignment on data-quality principles and policies\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003etechnology:\u003c/em\u003e strategic big data architecture and the identification of additional enablers, such as data ingestion, management platforms, and analytics and visualization tools\u003c/li\u003e \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eculture:\u003c/em\u003e change management during the transformation (for example, training and workshops) and an agile approach to ensure delivery\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nIt is also important to get to impact quickly. Too often, we see companies try expensive \u0026ldquo;big bang\u0026rdquo; approaches similar to mega IT projects, rather than treating analytics as a core capability to be developed over time. Instead, companies should focus on starting small and then scaling. The progression should involve identifying several high-value problems that analytics can solve, building specific data needs for the use cases, conducting pilots, and then developing the road map to scale.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\n2. Adjust mobile offerings to capture, secure, and serve the customer\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nMobile represents the most likely vector for disruption over the next five years, as capabilities are changing more rapidly than any other technology-driven platform for customer interaction. Today, customer behavior on mobile has distinct characteristics when compared with desktop, tablet, and offline:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eShorter user sessions.\u003c/em\u003e Mobile users engage with content for less than half the time of desktop Web users.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote35\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e35\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote35\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e35.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Raluca Budiu, \u0026ldquo;Mobile user experience: Limitations and strengths,\u0026rdquo; Nielsen Norman Group, April 19, 2015, nngroup.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eNo idle time.\u003c/em\u003e Mobile users rarely return to a previous browsing session, so a click away to another site is an exit, not a detour.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote36\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e36\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote36\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e36.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    Interviews with three travel industry e-commerce executives, August and September 2016.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003ePreoccupied user.\u003c/em\u003e Mobile users are often doing something else, such as standing in line, commuting, riding in an elevator, or sitting in a meeting.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote37\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e37\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote37\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e37.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eThe 2014 traveler\u0026rsquo;s road to decision\u003c/em\u003e, Google, June 2014, thinkwithgoogle.com, p. 27.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eSpecific goals.\u003c/em\u003e Typically, mobile users do not browse travel sites randomly but are looking for quick answers to precise questions such as rates and availability, product specifics (for example, operating hours), booking confirmation, or a purchase-transaction record.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote38\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e38\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote38\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e38.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u0026ldquo;How micro-moments are reshaping the travel customer journey,\u0026rdquo; Google, July 2016, thinkwithgoogle.com.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eZero tolerance.\u003c/em\u003e A mobile site or app must load quickly, respond accurately, and answer the query thoroughly\u0026mdash;or the user will abandon it (and likely not return).\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote39\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e39\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote39\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e39.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eThe 2014 traveler\u0026rsquo;s road to decision\u003c/em\u003e, Google, p. 37.\n    \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nToo often, companies start by asking, \u0026ldquo;How do I get people to use my app?\u0026rdquo; instead of focusing on creating mobile experiences that reflect customer usage. Remember that when a customer engages with a mobile website or app, navigation to the solution must be obvious and immediate. Smart design will store the most recent search or query (for example, airfares between LGA and LAX) and, in the case of a purchase transaction, suggest the most obvious next use. Similarly, if a traveler recently booked a hotel room, the platform should ask if he or she needs directions to the hotel or other destination details.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nFor companies wondering which platform\u0026mdash;mobile website or app\u0026mdash;to invest in, the answer is both. Most travelers are not loyal customers; for example, 50 percent of American Airlines\u0026rsquo; revenue in 2015 came from the 87 percent of its customers who flew AA only once that year.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote40\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e40\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote40\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e40.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nAdam Levine-Weinberg, \u0026ldquo;5 things American Airlines Group, Inc. wants you to know,\u0026rdquo; Motley Fool, October 30, 2015, fool.com.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e Such travelers are unlikely to download and keep your app.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nMobile sites, which are generally less expensive to develop, promote, and maintain, should provide a quick and easy booking and fact-finding experience, especially for infrequent customers. Apps should always be functional both on- and offline but should be developed specifically with offline utility and focused on loyal travelers, who are likely to make it one of their core apps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003e\n3. Safeguard against future disruptions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nOne of the most common questions we hear from clients today is, \u0026ldquo;How do I avoid being disrupted by the next Uber or Airbnb?\u0026rdquo; Most big companies are playing defense\u0026mdash;reacting to established competitors and upstarts\u0026mdash;instead of thinking about how they can identify and solve customer needs before somebody else does.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nMany in the industry are already establishing a more proactive stance. Airlines alone offer many examples: JetBlue launched a travel start-up investment arm, JetBlue Technology Ventures, in 2016, and invested in JetSuiteX in an attempt to capture the market between large commercial carriers and on-demand charters and private jets.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote41\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e41\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote41\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e41.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nLeena Rao, \u0026ldquo;Why JetBlue is landing in Silicon Valley,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eFortune\u003c/em\u003e, March 26, 2016; Doug Gollan, \u0026ldquo;JetSuiteX to launch scheduled flights in the West; Can a private jet airline be the next Southwest?\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eForbes\u003c/em\u003e, April 5, 2016.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e EasyJet took a stake in Founders Factory, which invests in start-ups, and has created a data-science team to explore operational applications of predictive artificial intelligence.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote42\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e42\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote42\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e42.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nPatrick Whyte, \u0026ldquo;EasyJet hopes its plan to invest in start-ups will help it stay ahead of competition,\u0026rdquo; skift.com, November 28, 2016; Derek du Preez, \u0026ldquo;EasyJet hires its first head of data science and posts record profits,\u0026rdquo; diginomica.com, November 17, 2015.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e And Emirates Group  partnered with Carnegie Mellon University to create the CMU-Emirates Silicon Valley Innovation Lab in an effort to put data at the center of its operations.\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote43\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e43\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote43\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e43.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nTara Rae Moore, \u0026ldquo;Emirates Group debuts Silicon Valley\u0026ndash;based innovation lab in partnership with Carnegie Mellon,\u0026rdquo; Carnegie Mellon University, November 3, 2015.\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nBeyond investments and partnerships, there are some approaches for executives to assess their organization\u0026rsquo;s vulnerability and identify possible solutions. These approaches cannot be theoretical and must be grounded in a simple objective: to identify unmet customer needs (largely among the existing customer base) that the company can solve before somebody else does.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eGrowth hacking. \u003c/em\u003eThis tactic, based on agile principles, is commonly used by start-ups to achieve rapid scale with limited resources. Companies should review all current revenue-generation initiatives and discretionary spending to determine which ones are being measured and tracked against overarching strategic objectives (for example, increasing customer lifetime value). Where necessary, they should implement new measures (for example, a customer feedback loop) and eliminate all activities that are \u0026ldquo;too intangible\u0026rdquo; to measure. Based on this insight, they can adjust business practices to amplify the high-performing initiatives and eliminate those that do not perform well.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cem\u003eSkunk Works.\u003c/em\u003e This approach involves selecting a cross-functional team of high achievers across multiple levels and assigning them to a special task force whose objective is to disrupt from within. This team should be tasked with developing new, independent offerings that compete with or replace existing products and services, complement the current business, or divert the profitability of the prevailing business model. The Skunk Works initiative, which may need to be carved out from the core day-to-day business to ensure independence, should launch new programs, products, and services to both current and new customers.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nEach of these approaches requires executives to take risks and embrace failure\u0026mdash;both rare traits in many established companies. At the same time, only new mistakes should be accepted, with shared learning celebrated at an institutional level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\nThe only constant in travel distribution is that innovators will thrive by identifying and addressing latent customer needs more effectively than traditional players. Most innovators don\u0026rsquo;t do it alone; as we discussed four years ago,\u003ca onclick=\"return false;\" href=\"#\" rel=\"#footnote44\" class=\"link-footnote\"\u003e\u003csup\u003e44\u003c/sup\u003e\u003c/a\u003e \u003cspan style=\"display: none;\" class=\"tooltip\" id=\"footnote44\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-content\"\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-number\"\u003e44.\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-text\"\u003e\nCarey, Kang, and Zea, \u0026ldquo;The trouble with travel distribution.\u0026rdquo;\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"clear\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan class=\"footnote-bottom\"\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e companies must unlock the power of partnerships to make progress in each of the three areas of customer centricity. The question now, with billions of dollars at stake, is whether change will again require a wave of new companies and models\u0026mdash;or whether current companies can rise to the challenge of putting the customer at the center.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[DisruptorSignUp full-width]]"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2017-02-27T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"contributoryPractice":{"targetItems":[]},"aboutTheAuthors":{"value":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRobert Carey\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey’s Atlanta office, where \u003cstrong\u003eDel Ross\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior adviser; Some customer-facing elements, such as side-by-side comparisons of room types, exist today, while other approaches to personalization have yet to take hold across the industry (exhibit).
